choices.text: Depression is the most common psychiatric disorder in the world.
Females have a higher lifetime risk of developing depression compared to males.
Depression is the most common cause of suicide.
Excluding tobacco use disorder, depression is the most common psychiatric disorder in India.

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct about depression EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression is the most common psychiatric disorder in the world.

 

Option A:

 

According to the World Mental Health Survey (WMHS) conducted by the World Health Organization (WHO), specific phobias are the most common psychiatric disorders worldwide.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Females have a higher lifetime risk of developing depression compared to males: This is correct. Depression is more common in females than males.

 

Option C. Depression is the most common cause of suicide: This statement is correct. 

 

Option D. Excluding tobacco use disorder, depression is the most common psychiatric disorder in India: According to the National Mental Health Survey (NMHS) conducted by the National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (NIMHANS) in India, the most common psychiatric disorder in India is depression, with a lifetime prevalence of 5.3%. However, if we specifically consider tobacco use disorder as a separate category, the prevalence is much higher. The NMHS found that the prevalence of current tobacco use in India was 28.6%, making it the most common substance use disorder in the country

 

Educational Objective:

 

While depression is a prevalent and disabling condition worldwide, anxiety disorders as a group may have a higher overall prevalence.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 393.

choices.text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors

questions.text: A 46-year-old male has been diagnosed with recurrent depressive disorder and has had four major depressive episodes in the last five years. Each episode was characterized by feelings of worthlessness, loss of interest in daily activities, fatigue, and decreased appetite. On each occasion, the episodes resolved with treatment but he is keen to avoid further episodes in the future. His psychiatrist is discussing options for prophylactic therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence. Which of the following drugs is NOT commonly used in the prophylaxis of recurrent depressive episodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Valproate

 

Option A.

 

Valproate (also known as valproic acid or divalproex sodium) is not commonly used in the prophylaxis of recurrent depressive episodes. Valproate is primarily used as a mood stabilizer in the treatment of bipolar disorder and as an anticonvulsant in the treatment of epilepsy. It is not typically used to prevent recurrent unipolar depression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lithium: Lithium is a well-established mood stabilizer that is often used for long-term prophylaxis in recurrent unipolar depressive disorder as well as in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): SSRIs are commonly prescribed for long-term maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence of depressive episodes in patients with recurrent unipolar depression.

 

Option D. Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs): TCAs are another class of antidepressants that can be used for long-term maintenance therapy in recurrent depressive disorder, although they are often less preferred than SSRIs due to their side effect profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of recurrent depressive disorder, common options for prophylactic therapy include lithium, SSRIs, and TCAs. Valproate, while a mood stabilizer and anticonvulsant, is not typically used for the prevention of recurrent unipolar depressive episodes.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 388-391.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to her psychiatrist with a history of depressive symptoms, including persistent sadness, anhedonia, fatigue, and difficulty concentrating. She was previously started on sertraline, which led to significant improvement in her symptoms. However, she discontinued the medication due to distressing side effects, including loss of sexual desire and weight gain. The psychiatrist is considering switching her to another antidepressant that would be less likely to cause these side effects. Which of the following antidepressants would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bupropion

 

Option A:

 

Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that acts as a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI). It is often the preferred antidepressant in patients who experience sexual side effects or weight gain with other antidepressants, as it has a lower likelihood of causing these issues. In this case, the patient's main concerns are the loss of sexual desire and weight gain, making bupropion (option A) the most appropriate choice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that is commonly associated with weight gain and increased appetite. Although mirtazapine is less likely to cause sexual side effects, the high likelihood of weigh gain rules it out in this patient.

 

Option C. Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It can cause both sexual side effects as well as weight gain similar to those experienced with sertraline.

 

Option D. Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) like sertraline and can cause both weight gain and loss of sexual desire.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients experiencing distressing sexual side effects and weight gain from SSRIs, bupropion is an appropriate alternative antidepressant due to its lower likelihood of causing these specific side effects.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 635-637.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient in her 2nd trimester of her second pregnancy presents with a 6-week history of persistent low mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of worthlessness. She reports having experienced a similar episode during her first pregnancy, which improved significantly with the addition of an antidepressant. Her current pregnancy has been uncomplicated thus far. The psychiatrist initially tried a course of cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) for 4 weeks, but her symptoms have not improved. Consequently, the psychiatrist decides to initiate pharmacological treatment for her significant depressive symptoms. Which one of the following antidepressants would be the most appropriate choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sertraline

 

Option B:

 

In a pregnant patient with depressive symptoms, the choice of antidepressant medication should be carefully considered due to potential risks to the developing fetus. Among the options provided, sertraline (B) is considered the safest choice during pregnancy. SSRIs as a group appear not to be major teratogens. And amongst the SSRIs, sertraline has the least placental exposure and hence is usually preferred over other SSRIs (such as A. fluoxetine and D. escitalopram) in pregnancy. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine and D. Escitalopram are SSRIs. But the placental exposure is more than that of Sertraline.

 

Option C. Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant, is less commonly used during pregnancy due to potential side effects and less favorable safety profile compared to SSRIs like sertraline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertraline is often the preferred choice for the pharmacological treatment of depression during pregnancy due to its relatively favorable safety profile and effectiveness. While other SSRIs like fluoxetine and escitalopram are also used, sertraline is preferred based on less placental exposure. Tricyclic antidepressants like imipramine are less commonly used due to their side effect profile.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 390-391.

choices.text: rTMS is considered more effective than ECT in the treatment of depression
rTMS is an invasive procedure, however, does not require the use of anesthetic agents
rTMS can cause seizures as a side effect
rTMS is a noninvasive procedure and there is no risk of seizures with rTMS

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with a history of major depressive disorder has not responded adequately to trials of multiple antidepressant medications and cognitive-behavioral therapy. Her psychiatrist is considering other treatment options and discusses repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) with the patient. Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of rTMS for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) rTMS can cause seizures as a side effect

 

Option C:

 

Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a noninvasive procedure that uses magnetic fields to stimulate specific brain regions. It has been shown to be effective in the treatment of major depressive disorder, particularly for patients who have not responded to conventional treatments like medication and psychotherapy. Although rTMS is generally considered safe, it can cause seizures as a rare side effect (option C).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. rTMS is considered more effective than ECT in the treatment of depression: This is incorrect, as ECT is generally considered more effective than rTMS in treating severe depression, but rTMS is favored in some cases due to its lower side effect profile. 

 

Option B. rTMS is an invasive procedure, however, does not require the use of anesthetic agents: This is incorrect because rTMS is a noninvasive procedure that does not require anesthesia. 

 

Option D. rTMS is a noninvasive procedure and there is no risk of seizures with rTMS: This is incorrect, as there is a risk of seizures with rTMS, although it is considered a rare side effect.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) is a noninvasive procedure used in the treatment of major depressive disorder, especially in cases resistant to medications and psychotherapy. It uses rapidly changing magnetic fields to produce small electric currents (known as eddy currents) in superficial cortical neurons. It is non-convulsive, no anesthesia required. While generally safe, rTMS does carry a rare but serious risk of inducing seizures. It is not considered more effective than ECT and does not require anesthesia, distinguishing it as a less invasive alternative.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 737.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male teacher presents to his primary care physician with a 4-year history of depressive symptoms. He reports feeling constantly down and having low energy, with occasional trouble concentrating and making decisions. His sleep and appetite disturbances are also occasional. Despite his symptoms, the patient continues to go to work regularly. He notes that when he is with other people, he sometimes feels better, but mostly he feels low. The patient's symptoms have been persistent but relatively stable over the past four years. Based on the patient's clinical presentation, which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

 

Option C:

 

The patient's ability to function at work, along with occasional improvements in mood when with others, and the stable nature of his symptoms over a long period suggest dysthymia as the most likely diagnosis. Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) is characterized by a milder yet more enduring depressive mood that lasts for at least two years. 

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. Major Depressive Disorder typically presents with more severe symptoms and significant impairment in daily functioning, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation. 

 

Option B. Bipolar Disorder involves episodes of mania or hypomania in addition to depressive episodes, which are not reported in this case. 

 

Option D. Generalized Anxiety Disorder is primarily characterized by excessive and persistent worry, which does not match the primary complaints of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia) is the presence of mild depressive symptoms (not enough to diagnose a major depressive episode) for a period of more than two years (and at least one year in children and adolescents). While the symptoms might not be as severe as those in major depressive disorder, they are chronic and persistent.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 382.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a 3-month history of symptoms characterized by persistent low mood, anhedonia, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, and feelings of worthlessness. Over the last two weeks, she has started hearing a scary voice telling her, "You are a bad woman and will be punished." What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoxetine plus risperidone

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation suggests a diagnosis of major depressive disorder with psychotic features. In addition to the depressive symptoms, she is experiencing auditory hallucinations, which is indicative of the psychotic component of her illness.

 

For the treatment of major depressive disorder with psychotic features, a combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic is recommended. In this case, fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), would address the depressive symptoms, while risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic, would target the psychotic symptoms. Therefore, option B, fluoxetine plus risperidone, is the preferred treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fluoxetine alone, may be effective for treating the depressive symptoms but would not address the psychotic symptoms. 

 

Option C. Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic and would target the psychotic symptoms but may not be sufficient for treating the depressive symptoms. 

 

Option D. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) could be a helpful adjunctive treatment for managing the depressive symptoms, but it is not the primary treatment choice in this case due to the presence of psychotic features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with major depressive disorder with psychotic features, the preferred treatment often involves a combination of an antidepressant and an antipsychotic to effectively address both the depressive and psychotic symptoms. Fluoxetine can treat the depressive symptoms, while risperidone can manage the psychotic symptoms.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 390-391.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with sadness of mood, frequent crying spells, insomnia, occasional suicidal thoughts, and lack of energy. The psychiatrist decides to start him on antidepressants, but the patient mentions that he is about to get married in one month and is concerned about the potential sexual side effects of the medication. Which of the following antidepressants should be prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mirtazapine

 

Option C:

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of depression, and it is appropriate to initiate the antidepressant therapy. However, the patient's concern regarding potential sexual side effects should be taken into consideration when choosing the appropriate medication.

 

Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that acts as a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA). Mirtazapine has a lower incidence of sexual side effects compared to SSRIs and SNRIs, making it a suitable choice for this patient who is concerned about the potential impact on his sexual function. Apart from mirtazapine, bupropion is another antidepressant that has a very low incidence of sexual side effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is commonly used to treat depression. However, SSRIs are known to cause sexual side effects such as decreased libido, delayed ejaculation, and poor erection in some patients.

 

Option B. Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression. While SNRIs are also effective in treating depression, they may cause similar sexual side effects as SSRIs due to their effect on serotonin.

 

Option D. Escitalopram is another SSRI used to treat depression. Like sertraline, it may cause sexual side effects due to its impact on serotonin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mirtazapine belongs to a class called NSSA (nor adrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant). The mechanism of action is antagonism of central presynaptic a2 (alpha2) receptors which results in increased firing of norepinephrine and serotonin neurons. The other important action is antagonism of postsynaptic serotonin 5 HT2 and 5 HT3 receptors. Mirtazapine causes sedation and weight gain but doesn't have problematic sexual side effects. Other side effects include dry mouth, constipation, myalgia and disturbing dreams.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 637.

questions.text:
The neurobiological changes in depression are characterized by which of the following statements?

 

  1. Decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex
  2. Increased activity in the prefrontal cortex
  3. Decreased activity in the amygdala
  4. Increased activity in the amygdala
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 4 are correct

 

Option B:

 

1. Decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex: Neuroimaging studies in patients with depression often show reduced activity in the prefrontal cortex. This area of the brain is involved in executive functions such as decision-making, problem-solving, and regulating emotions. Decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex is associated with impaired cognitive function and emotional regulation in depression.

 

4. Increased activity in the amygdala: The amygdala plays a crucial role in processing emotions, especially negative emotions like fear and sadness. In depression, there is often increased activity in the amygdala, which is associated with heightened processing of negative emotions and contributes to the persistent negative mood characteristic of depression.

 

Explanation:

 

2. Increased activity in the prefrontal cortex: This statement is generally incorrect in the context of depression. As mentioned, decreased rather than increased activity is typically observed in the prefrontal cortex in depressed patients.

 

3. Decreased activity in the amygdala: This statement is incorrect for depression. Increased, rather than decreased, activity in the amygdala is often associated with depression, related to the enhanced processing of negative emotions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurobiological changes in depression typically include decreased activity in the prefrontal cortex, which is associated with impaired cognitive and emotional regulation, and increased activity in the amygdala, which is related to heightened negative emotional processing.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 396.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of depression is being treated with escitalopram. He was recently prescribed thiazide diuretics for newly diagnosed hypertension. He presents to the emergency department with acute onset confusion and disorientation. Laboratory workup is initiated to identify the cause of his symptoms. Considering his medication regimen and the potential side effects, what is the most likely cause of his confusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyponatremia

 

Option A:

 

Hyponatremia is a common cause of confusion, especially in older adults and those taking medications that can lead to SIADH. This is the most likely cause given the patient's medication history and presenting symptoms.

 

This patient’s recent initiation of a thiazide diuretic in combination with escitalopram, an SSRI, puts him at an increased risk for hyponatremia. SSRIs can cause the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), leading to hyponatremia. Thiazide diuretics can exacerbate this effect by increasing the reabsorption of water. The patient’s confusion and disorientation are consistent with the neurological symptoms seen in hyponatremia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Hypokalemia can cause confusion but is less likely in this context. Thiazide diuretics are more commonly associated with hypokalemia, but the patient's use of escitalopram points towards hyponatremia.

 

Option C: Drug interactions: While drug interactions are possible, the symptoms and context provided are more indicative of hyponatremia due to the combined effects of escitalopram and the thiazide diuretic.

 

Option D: Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition resulting from an excess of serotonin. Symptoms include agitation, confusion, rapid heartbeat, and high blood pressure. While the patient is on escitalopram, there is no indication of serotonin syndrome in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSRIs can cause hyponatremia. The onset is usually within 30 days of starting treatment. The mechanism is SIADH. It can happen particularly in older adults, females and when used in combination with other medications like diuretics, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors etc. 

 

Management depends upon the serum sodium levels. 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 394-395.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman seeks help after experiencing symptoms of depressed mood, diminished appetite, difficulty sleeping, persistent fatigue, and a general disinterest in her surroundings for the past year. She mentions these feelings began after she faced a personal problem 12 months ago. What is the most probable diagnosis for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Major depressive disorder

 

Option C:

 

The symptoms described by the 45-year-old woman align with the criteria for Major Depressive Disorder (MDD). MDD is characterized by a persistently depressed mood and/or loss of interest or pleasure in almost all activities, accompanied by other symptoms such as changes in appetite or weight, sleep disturbances, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, diminished ability to think or concentrate, and recurrent thoughts of death or suicide. These symptoms must be present most of the day, nearly every day for at least two weeks. In this case, the patient has experienced these symptoms for about a year supports the diagnosis of MDD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Adjustment Disorder: While adjustment disorders involve emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to a stressor, these symptoms typically occur within three months of the stressor and tend to resolve within six months after the stressor or its consequences have ended. The duration and nature of her symptoms extend beyond the typical scope of an adjustment disorder. It does not meet the criteria of MDD.

 

Option B: Conversion Disorder: This involves neurological symptoms that are incompatible with neurological pathways and cannot be explained by a medical or neurological condition. There is no indication in the scenario of such symptoms.

 

Option D: Malingering: This involves the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms, motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work or obtaining financial compensation. There is no indication in the scenario to suggest malingering.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 381.

questions.text: A patient has been prescribed escitalopram for the treatment of anxiety. During a follow-up visit, the patient inquires about potential side effects of the medication. Which of the following is not a common side effect of escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Option D.

 

Sialorrhea is not a common side effect of escitalopram. Dry mouth is more frequently reported with the use of SSRIs.

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that is commonly used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. Like other SSRIs, it has a range of potential side effects. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nausea is a well-known and common side effect of escitalopram, especially when the medication is first initiated or when the dose is increased.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams or nightmares can occur with the use of escitalopram, though they are not as common as other side effects.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia is a known sexual side effect of SSRIs, including escitalopram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sialorrhea (excessive salivation) is not a common side effect of escitalopram. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.

choices.text: Start fluoxetine for 4 weeks, and in case of no improvement, offer ECT

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with a history of recurrent depressive disorder presents to the clinic with symptoms of depression that began 8 weeks ago. His past medical history is significant for two previous episodes of major depression in the past five years, both of which were managed with a combination of pharmacotherapy and psychotherapy. He reports a gradual increase in the severity of his symptoms over the past two months, characterized by a persistent low mood, anhedonia, insomnia, and feelings of guilt and worthlessness. His appetite has also decreased, and he has lost 5 kg during this period. The patient's family reports that he has become increasingly socially withdrawn and has stopped engaging in his usual hobbies. Three days ago, he attempted suicide and was about to hang himself, but was saved by a family member who intervened just before the attempt was made. The patient is currently not receiving any treatment. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Offer electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)

 

Option C:

 

In this case, the patient has a history of recurrent depressive disorder and a recent suicide attempt, indicating the severity of his condition. In patients with high suicide risk, it is essential to choose a treatment modality that can provide rapid symptom relief and minimize the risk of another suicide attempt.

 

Option C, offering electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), is the most appropriate choice in this scenario. ECT is an effective treatment for severe depression, particularly when there is a high risk of suicide or when other treatments have not been successful. ECT often provides a more rapid response compared to pharmacotherapy or psychotherapy alone, making it a suitable choice for this patient.

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. Starting fluoxetine or B. initiating CBT sessions may eventually be beneficial for the patient, but they are less likely to provide the rapid symptom relief needed in this urgent situation. 

 

Option D. Starting SSRIs for 4 weeks and offering ECT only if there is no improvement, delays the potential benefits of ECT and may not adequately address the immediate risk of another suicide attempt.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe cases of depression, particularly when accompanied by suicidal ideation and lack of response to medication, ECT is often the most effective and rapid treatment. ECT is indicated when there is a need for a quick and robust response, especially when there is a high risk of suicide.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 393.

choices.text: Esketamine is administered orally as an adjunctive treatment
Esketamine is administered intravenously as an adjunctive treatment
Esketamine is administered intranasally as an adjunctive treatment
Esketamine is contraindicated in patients with a history of substance abuse

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with treatment-resistant major depressive disorder presents to the clinic. Despite multiple trials of various medications and cognitive-behavioral therapy, his depressive symptoms have persisted. His psychiatrist is considering the use of esketamine as an adjunctive treatment. Which of the following statements is true regarding the use of esketamine for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esketamine is administered intranasally as an adjunctive treatment

 

Option C:

 

Esketamine is a derivative of ketamine and has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of treatment-resistant depression. It is used as an adjunctive treatment alongside an oral antidepressant. Esketamine is administered intranasally, which distinguishes it from ketamine, which is typically administered intravenously. 

 

Explanation: 

 

Option A. is incorrect, as esketamine is not administered orally. 

 

Option B. is incorrect because esketamine is not administered intravenously. 

 

Option D. is also incorrect, as esketamine is not contraindicated in patients with a history of substance abuse, although caution and monitoring are advised in such cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esketamine is approved for use as an adjunctive treatment for treatment-resistant major depressive disorder in adults and is administered intranasally. It offers a novel treatment option for patients who have not responded to other antidepressant therapies.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 648.

choices.text: Inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes.
Blockade of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake.

questions.text: During a weekly teaching session at the psychiatric residency program, Dr. Suresh Kumar presents a case of a 35-year-old male patient who recently began treatment for smoking cessation. The patient also has a history of depressive episodes but dislikes the sexual side effects he previously experienced with another antidepressant. Dr. Kumar prescribed bupropion not only for its efficacy in smoking cessation but also for its potential antidepressant effects without the sexual side effects commonly seen with some other classes of antidepressants. He then posed a question to the residents: "Considering its unique profile, what best describes the primary mechanism of action of bupropion that differentiates it from many other antidepressants?"
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blockade of norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake.

 

Option C:

 

Bupropion primarily inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine, thereby increasing their concentrations in the synaptic cleft. This is its primary mechanism that sets it apart from SSRIs and some other classes of antidepressants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Potentiation of serotonin neurotransmission: This is the primary mechanism of SSRIs and some other classes of antidepressants, but not bupropion. Bupropion does not have significant activity on serotonin receptors.

 

Option B: Inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes: MAO inhibitors act by inhibiting the enzyme monoamine oxidase, thus preventing the breakdown of monoamine neurotransmitters and thereby increasing their availability. Bupropion is not an MAOI.

 

Option D: Enhancement of GABAergic activity: This is a mechanism associated with benzodiazepines and certain antiepileptic medications, not with bupropion.

 

Educational objective:

 

Bupropion belongs to a class called NDRI (norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitors). The mechanism of action is inhibition of reuptake of both norepinephrine and dopamine. The advantage of bupropion is a good side effect profile with low risk of sexual side effects, weight gain or sedation. The common side effects are insomnia, tremors, restlessness and nausea. A particular worrisome side effect is seizures (usually seen at higher dosages). Bupropion is also used for smoking cessation.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 635-637.

choices.text: Suicidal tendencies with overdose of Amitriptyline
Therapeutic drug monitoring of Amitriptyline
Prescribing modafinil to counteract sedation due to Amitriptyline

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with a history of severe depression is admitted to the psychiatric unit for treatment. He has been started on Amitriptyline and, after 4 weeks of therapy, shows significant improvement in his depressive symptoms. He no longer reports feelings of hopelessness and has started to engage more with his family and hospital staff. As his physician, you are preparing for his discharge and considering the potential risks associated with his medication at this stage of treatment. At the time of his discharge, which of the following is the most important concern with Amitriptyline therapy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suicidal tendencies with overdose of Amitriptyline

 

Option A.

 

The most important concern with Amitriptyline at the time of discharge is the risk of suicidal tendencies and the potential for overdose. Tricyclic antidepressants can be lethal in overdose due to their cardiovascular and neurological toxicity. As the patient's depressive symptoms improve and he gains more energy and motivation, there may still be a risk of suicidal ideation (known as paradoxical suicide), and the lethality of Amitriptyline in overdose makes this a critical concern.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Therapeutic drug monitoring of Amitriptyline: While important in the long-term management to ensure therapeutic levels and prevent toxicity, it is not typically the most critical concern at discharge.

 

Option C. ECG monitoring for arrhythmias: Amitriptyline can cause cardiac arrhythmias, particularly in overdose or in patients with pre-existing heart conditions. Regular ECG monitoring is advisable but secondary to the concern of suicidal tendencies in the immediate discharge period.

 

Option D. Prescribing modafinil to counteract sedation due to Amitriptyline: While Amitriptyline can cause sedation, addressing the risk of suicidal ideation and overdose is a more pressing concern. Modafinil is not commonly prescribed solely to counteract sedation from antidepressants and has its own set of considerations and potential side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In certain cases, a person with depression might die by suicide while their symptoms show signs of improvement after beginning antidepressant treatment. This is referred to as paradoxical suicide, as it occurs when symptoms have already started to improve. The hypothesis is that a depressed individual may not have the energy to act on suicidal thoughts initially; however, as their condition begins to improve, their energy levels increase before their suicidal thoughts subside. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman, who has been on an antidepressant for the past year, is planning to discontinue her medication due to perceived improvement in her mood. She has heard stories about people experiencing unpleasant symptoms when stopping their antidepressants and is concerned about experiencing the same. Which of the following medications, if she was taking, would be the least likely to result in a discontinuation reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoxetine

 

Option B:

 

Fluoxetine is the least likely to result in a discontinuation reaction among the options listed. Fluoxetine has a long half-life, which allows it to taper off gradually from the body even after discontinuation. This gradual tapering reduces the risk of experiencing discontinuation syndrome. Discontinuation syndrome, which is characterized by symptoms such as flu-like symptoms, insomnia, nausea, imbalance, sensory disturbances, and hyperarousal, can occur after stopping antidepressants, especially those with a short half-life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Venlafaxine: This is an SNRI (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) known for its potential to cause significant discontinuation syndrome, especially at higher doses, due to its short half-life. 

 

Option C: Paroxetine: This SSRI has a short half-life and is also known for causing discontinuation symptoms.

 

Option D: Citalopram: While it has a longer half-life than venlafaxine or paroxetine, it is still more likely to produce discontinuation symptoms than fluoxetine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discontinuation syndrome (often incorrectly referred to as "withdrawal") are symptoms that can occur when the dose of antidepressants is reduced or stopped abruptly. All antidepressants can cause discontinuation syndrome. Venlafaxine is most commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Fluoxetine, which is the long acting SSRI, is least likely to be associated with discontinuation syndrome. Therefore, the likelihood of experiencing discontinuation reactions can vary depending on the half-life of the drug; those with shorter half-lives tend to produce these reactions more frequently. 

 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 343-346.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of persistent low mood, difficulty sleeping, and feelings of worthlessness for the past 6 months. She reports that these symptoms have interfered with her daily activities and have negatively affected her relationships. Her medical history is unremarkable, and she is not currently on any medication. The patient mentions that she and her partner are planning to conceive a baby in the near future. The physician is considering recommending a treatment option for her depressive symptoms. Which of the following treatment options is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT). 

 

Option C:

 

Given the patient's significant depressive symptoms and her plans to conceive, Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is an appropriate and safe initial treatment option. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is an evidence-based psychological treatment for depression that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors. It has been shown to be effective in treating mild to moderate depression. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Regular exercise is beneficial for mental health and can be recommended as an adjunctive treatment for mild to moderate depression. However, given the severity and duration of the patient's symptoms, exercise alone might not be sufficient as the sole treatment.

 

Option B. Counseling can be helpful for individuals with depression, and it may involve various therapeutic approaches, including supportive therapy. However, CBT is a more structured form of psychotherapy with a strong evidence base for the treatment of depression, making it a preferred option in this scenario.

 

Option D. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressants are effective for treating depression, but their use in women who are planning to conceive requires careful consideration due to potential risks during pregnancy. If non-pharmacological treatments like CBT are effective, they may be preferred to avoid potential medication-related risks during preconception and pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For individuals with depression, especially those planning pregnancy, Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is an effective and safe initial treatment option. CBT provides a non-pharmacological approach to manage depressive symptoms and does not carry the potential risks associated with medication use during preconception and pregnancy.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 392.

choices.text: Negative views of the future

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with persistent feelings of sadness over the past six months. She describes her mood as "consistently low" and admits to having lost interest in activities she once enjoyed. She often feels tired and has trouble sleeping. When asked about her thought patterns, she describes feeling "worthless," believes that "everything is against her," and fears "nothing will ever get better." Based on her described thought patterns, which of the following is NOT part of the cognitive triad as described by Beck?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Guilt

 

Option D:

 

Guilt, although frequently seen in depressed patients, is not one of the three core components of Beck's cognitive triad.

 

Explanation:

 

Aaron Beck's cognitive triad is a model used to describe the thought patterns frequently seen in patients with depression. According to this triad, individuals with depression have:

 

Option A: Negative views of the future: They often feel hopeless and believe that their situation won't improve.

 

Option B: Negative views of self: This can manifest as feelings of worthlessness, self-blame, or inadequacy.

 

Option C: Helplessness: They feel that there is nothing they can do to change the negative situations in their lives.

 

Educational objective:

 

The cognitive theory of depression was proposed by Aaron T Beck. According to this theory, negative thoughts have a central role in the development of depression. Beck proposed that there are three central thoughts/ideas in depression, the so-called cognitive triad of depression.

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 399.

choices.text: Depression with psychotic symptoms

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the psychiatric clinic reporting persistent sadness, lack of interest in activities, decreased sleep, and appetite over the past 6 months. Recently, he has started to experience “hearing of voices” commanding him to ‘kill himself’. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Depression with psychotic symptoms

 

Option B:

 

The patient’s prolonged period of sadness, lack of interest, decreased sleep, and appetite suggest a depressive episode. The onset of auditory hallucinations, especially with self-harm commands, introduces psychotic features to the clinical picture. Depression with psychotic symptoms is characterized by a depressive episode accompanied by psychotic features such as hallucinations or delusions. The psychotic symptoms typically align with the mood (congruent) but can also be mood incongruent. The duration and nature of symptoms fit this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Schizophrenia is characterized by at least 6 months of continuous disturbance, with at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms, including two or more of the following: delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, disorganized or catatonic behavior, or negative symptoms. The patient’s prominent mood symptoms and the duration of his condition make this less likely.

 

Option C: Bipolar disorder (mixed episode) could present with depressive and manic symptoms concurrently, but the patient does not exhibit manic symptoms, making this option less likely.

 

Option D: Schizophreniform disorder involves symptoms similar to schizophrenia but lasts for 1-6 months. Given the 6-month duration of this patient’s symptoms, this is less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psychotic depression is characterized by presence of depressive symptoms with delusions/hallucinations. Psychotic symptoms can be mood congruent/mood incongruent. If the content of delusions/hallucinations matches with the mood, it's called mood congruent, if it doesnt match, it's called mood incongruent. E.g. A patient with severe depression develops a delusion that the world is ending. It is an example of mood-congruent delusion.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a six-month history of severe depression. She reports persistent low mood, lack of pleasure in activities, and significant weight loss. During the clinical interview, she exhibits slowed speech and movement. Based on her presentation, which of the following is not characteristic of melancholic depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initial insomnia

 

Option C:

 

Initial insomnia, which is difficulty falling asleep, is not associated with melancholic depression. Patients with melancholic depression usually experience terminal insomnia, which is early morning awakening.

 

Melancholic depression is a subtype of major depressive disorder characterized by specific features such as profound sadness, lack of reactivity to pleasurable stimuli, distinct quality of mood, and worsening of symptoms in the morning. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Psychomotor agitation, which includes restlessness and pacing, can be seen in melancholic depression. 

 

Option B: Profound guilt is a common symptom in melancholic depression, where individuals may experience excessive and inappropriate feelings of guilt and worthlessness.

 

Option D: Diurnal mood fluctuation, where mood is worse in the morning and improves as the day goes on, is characteristic of melancholic depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melancholic depression, also known as involutional melancholia is a type of Depression with melancholic features is usually seen in old age, and is characterised by the following features:

 

  1. Prominent biological symptoms:
    1. Early morning awakening (waking up at least 2 hours before usual time) 
    2.  Significant anorexia and weight loss
  2. Significant psychomotor agitation or retardation
  3. Anhedonia and lack of mood reactivity (i.e. the patient's mood doesn't improve even if some positive event occurs)
  4. A distinct quality of intensely depressed mood, often referred to as a state of despondency or despair, also called as empty mood. The patients feels miserable.
  5. Depression is worse in the morning
  6. Excessive guilt.
     

These patients have a higher suicide risk.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 380-382.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man visits his primary care physician, reporting new-onset dry mouth, constipation, and blurred vision. He mentions that he was recently prescribed amitriptyline for depression. Which receptor's antagonism by amitriptyline is most likely responsible for the side effects he's experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muscarinic

 

Option C:

 

The side effects of dry mouth, constipation, and blurred vision experienced by the patient are characteristic of anticholinergic side effects, which are caused by the antagonism of muscarinic receptors. Amitriptyline, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), has significant anticholinergic properties due to its muscarinic receptor antagonism.

 

  • Dry mouth and constipation are anticholinergic side effects resulting from reduced salivary and gastrointestinal secretions, respectively.
  • Blurred vision can also occur due to the effect of muscarinic antagonism on the ciliary muscles of the eye.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dopamine: Dopamine receptor antagonism is more characteristic of antipsychotic medications and can lead to extrapyramidal side effects, but it is not typically associated with the symptoms the patient is experiencing.

 

Option B: Histamine: Histamine (H1) receptor antagonism can cause sedation and weight gain, which are also side effects of TCAs, but they are not responsible for the dry mouth, constipation, and blurred vision.

 

Option D: Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine reuptake inhibition is a mechanism of action of TCAs in treating depression but does not directly cause the anticholinergic side effects mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 642.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by her roommate, who found her drowsy next to an empty pill bottle. The patient is lethargic with a blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. On examination, her pupils are dilated, and her mouth is dry. An ECG shows a wide QRS complex with a rightward axis. The empty pill bottle previously contained an older type of antidepressant medication. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sodium bicarbonate

 

Option C:

 

The clinical findings are consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose. The symptoms of lethargy, hypotension, dilated pupils, dry mouth, and particularly the ECG findings of a wide QRS complex with a rightward axis are consistent with TCA toxicity. The most appropriate immediate intervention in this case is C) Sodium bicarbonate. TCA overdose can lead to cardiac conduction abnormalities, including widening of the QRS complex due to its sodium channel-blocking effects. Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat TCA overdose as it helps to overcome the sodium channel blockade, narrows the QRS complex, and corrects the acidosis often associated with the overdose.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hemodialysis is not effective in removing TCAs from the body due to their high protein binding and large volume of distribution.

 

Option B: Flumazenil is an antagonist used to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines, not TCAs.

 

Option D: Fomepizole is an antidote for toxic alcohol ingestion (such as methanol and ethylene glycol), not for TCA overdose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 644.

questions.text: Tricyclic antidepressants are contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Glaucoma

 

Option A:

 

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are contraindicated in patients with glaucoma, especially closed-angle glaucoma. TCAs have anticholinergic properties which can lead to an increase in intraocular pressure, thereby exacerbating glaucoma. Their anticholinergic effects can cause pupil dilation, potentially worsening the angle closure in patients with closed-angle glaucoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Brain tumor: While not an absolute contraindication, TCAs should be used cautiously in patients with a brain tumor, particularly if there is increased intracranial pressure, as the anticholinergic effects can potentially worsen certain symptoms.

 

Option C: Bronchial asthma: TCAs might not be contraindicated in asthma, but caution is advised due to their anticholinergic effects, which can potentially affect bronchial secretions and muscle tone.

 

Option D: Hypertension: TCAs can be used in patients with hypertension, but with caution, as they can cause orthostatic hypotension, so careful monitoring would be necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) possess anticholinergic properties, which can lead to a variety of side effects. One of the primary concerns with the anticholinergic action of TCAs is the potential to precipitate an acute narrow-angle glaucoma attack in susceptible individuals. Hence, TCAs are contraindicated in patients with narrow-angle glaucoma. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 642.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with tremors, hyperreflexia, and diaphoresis. On examination, she has dilated pupils and her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Her medical history reveals she started on an SSRI for depression two weeks ago. Additionally, she mentions taking another medication, the name of which she could not recall. Given her presentation and concurrent medications, which agents, when combined with SSRIs, can elevate serotonin levels and potentially result in the observed clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation of the patient, characterized by tremors, hyperreflexia, diaphoresis, dilated pupils, and elevated temperature, is suggestive of serotonin syndrome. Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition resulting from increased serotonin activity in the central nervous system. It can occur when certain drugs that increase serotonin levels are taken together.

 

The agents listed can all elevate serotonin levels when combined with SSRIs:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Lithium: While primarily used as a mood stabilizer in bipolar disorder, lithium can increase serotonin levels and, when combined with SSRIs, may contribute to serotonin syndrome.

 

Option B: MAOIs (Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors): These antidepressants inhibit the enzyme monoamine oxidase, which breaks down serotonin. Combining MAOIs with SSRIs can lead to excessive serotonin accumulation and a high risk of serotonin syndrome.

 

Option C: Sumatriptan: This is a medication used for migraine treatment and is a serotonin receptor agonist. When combined with SSRIs, there is an increased risk of serotonin syndrome due to additive effects on serotonin levels.

 

The combination of any of these agents with an SSRI can increase the risk of developing serotonin syndrome. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concurrent administration of an SSRI with MAO inhibitor, L-tryptophan or lithium can raise plasma serotonin concentration, resulting in serotonin syndrome. It is a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

 

Management includes discontinuation of serotonergic agents (most crucial), supportive care and cyproheptadine.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 337.

choices.text: None of the above

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to his primary care physician complaining of difficulties in his intimate relationship. He mentions that ever since he started a medication for his depressive symptoms three months ago, he has experienced a decreased libido and difficulty maintaining an erection. He denies any cardiovascular issues, and his physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fluoxetine

 

Option A:

 

The patient's symptoms of decreased libido and erectile dysfunction, which started after initiating a medication for depression, are likely side effects of his antidepressant. Among the options provided, fluoxetine, which is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is most commonly associated with sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido and difficulty maintaining an erection.

 

  • Fluoxetine and other SSRIs are well-known to cause sexual side effects due to their mechanism of action on serotonin pathways. Increased serotonin can inhibit sexual desire, arousal, and orgasm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Mirtazapine: This works as a noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA), is generally less likely to cause sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs and SNRIs.

 

Option C: Bupropion: This is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor (NDRI) and is actually associated with a lower risk of sexual side effects. In some cases, it is used to counteract sexual dysfunction caused by SSRIs and SNRIs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido and difficulty maintaining an erection, is a common side effect of SSRIs like fluoxetine. These medications increase serotonin levels, which can adversely affect sexual desire and performance. In contrast, antidepressants like mirtazapine and bupropion are less likely to cause sexual dysfunction and may even be used to mitigate these side effects when they occur with other antidepressants.

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • The most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection, and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE, etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 628-630.

questions.text: A patient with depression is being evaluated for pharmacological treatment options. The healthcare provider aims to choose a medication and dose that is within the accepted therapeutic range for treating depression. Which of the following drug and dose combinations has been correctly matched with its adequate antidepressant dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fluoxetine 20 mg

 

Option B:

 

The typical starting dose for fluoxetine in the treatment of depression is 20 mg once daily. This dose is considered within the accepted therapeutic range and can be effective in managing depressive symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fluoxetine 10 mg: While 10 mg can be a starting dose for some patients, especially those who may be sensitive to medication side effects, it is generally on the lower end of the therapeutic range for depression. The more standard starting dose is 20 mg.

 

Option C: Amitriptyline 25 mg: Its therapeutic dose for depression generally starts at around 75 mg per day, which can be increased as needed and tolerated. A dose of 25 mg is considered subtherapeutic for depression, although it may be used for other indications like chronic pain or migraines.

 

Option D: Amitriptyline 10 mg: This dose is also subtherapeutic for depression and is more likely to be used for other indications like chronic pain or migraines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical starting dose of fluoxetine for the treatment of depression is 20 mg once daily, which is within the accepted therapeutic range. Lower doses of fluoxetine and lower doses of amitriptyline (such as 10 mg or 25 mg) are generally considered subtherapeutic for depression.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 631.

choices.text: Depression can increase the risk of myocardial infarction.
Experiencing a myocardial infarction can predispose to depression.
SSRIs can be prescribed safely after a myocardial infarction to address depressive symptoms.
Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man, recently hospitalized for a myocardial infarction, is seen in the cardiology clinic for follow-up. He reports feeling persistently sad, fatigued and has lost interest in activities he previously enjoyed. He admits to feeling "worthless" since his hospitalization. His cardiologist wants to address his mood symptoms and is considering the next steps in management. Which of the following statements regarding his condition and potential interventions is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction.

 

Option D:

 

This patient's symptoms of persistent sadness, fatigue, anhedonia, and feelings of worthlessness suggest he is suffering from depression following his myocardial infarction (MI). 

 

The statement that "Only cognitive behavioral therapy should be recommended after myocardial infarction" is false. While cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a valuable treatment for depression and can be used in patients following a myocardial infarction (MI), it is not the only option for managing depressive symptoms in this population. Antidepressant medications, particularly selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), are also considered safe and effective in treating depression in patients who have experienced an MI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Depression can increase the risk of myocardial infarction: This is true. Depression is associated with an increased risk of coronary artery disease and subsequent MI.

 

Option B: Experiencing a myocardial infarction can predispose to depression: This is also true. The experience of having an MI can be psychologically traumatic, and the subsequent lifestyle changes and health concerns can contribute to the development of depression.

 

Option C: SSRIs can be prescribed safely after a myocardial infarction to address depressive symptoms: This is true. SSRIs are generally considered safe in patients with heart disease and can be used to treat depression following an MI. They are preferred over other antidepressant classes like tricyclic antidepressants, which can have adverse cardiac effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Depression is common after a myocardial infarction and can affect recovery and outcomes. Both pharmacological (e.g., SSRIs) and non-pharmacological (e.g., CBT) interventions can be effective in treating post-MI depression.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 386.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of treatment-resistant depression is under consideration for additional therapies to augment her current antidepressant regimen. Her psychiatrist is considering adding a hormone to her treatment plan to potentially boost the efficacy of her current medication. Which of the following hormones is most commonly used as an adjunct in the treatment of depression?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levothyroxine

 

Option B:

 

Levothyroxine is sometimes used as an adjunct in the treatment of depression, particularly in cases of treatment-resistant depression. While the primary use of levothyroxine is to treat hypothyroidism, it has been found to be effective in augmenting antidepressant therapy, even in patients with normal thyroid function. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cortisol: Cortisol is a stress hormone produced by the adrenal glands. Elevated levels of cortisol are often associated with stress and may be counterproductive in the treatment of depression.

 

Option C: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic hormone): ACTH stimulates the release of cortisol from the adrenal glands and is not used as a treatment for depression.

 

Option D: Progesterone: Progesterone is a sex hormone that plays a role in the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. It is not commonly used as an adjunct in the treatment of depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Levothyroxine can be used as an adjunct therapy in the treatment of depression, particularly for patients with treatment-resistant depression. It can be effective even in patients without overt hypothyroidism.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 321.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic three months after suffering from a left-sided hemiplegic stroke. He reports persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a lack of interest in activities he once enjoyed. His family notes that he's become more withdrawn and less communicative since the stroke. He has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. The psychiatrist considers pharmacological intervention for his depressive symptoms. Which of the following medications would be the most appropriate choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SSRI

 

Option B:

 

This patient's presentation is consistent with post-stroke depression, which is a common consequence following a cerebrovascular accident. It can result in both physical and emotional symptoms, negatively impacting recovery and overall quality of life. SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors) are the first-line treatment for post-stroke depression due to their efficacy, safety profile, and generally fewer side effects compared to older antidepressants. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Buspirone: It's an anxiolytic that's mainly used for generalized anxiety disorder and is not a first-line treatment for depression.

 

Option C: Nootropic drugs: These are cognitive enhancers that are not typically used as primary treatments for depression.

 

Option D: Amitriptyline: It's a tricyclic antidepressant. While effective for depression, it has a less favorable side effect profile compared to SSRIs, especially in elderly patients. It can cause anticholinergic effects, orthostatic hypotension, and can be cardiotoxic. Given the patient's age and stroke history, an SSRI would be a safer choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SSRIs are preferred for post-stroke depression, especially in those with hypertension. 

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 362.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a painful erection lasting for the past 5 hours. He denies any recent trauma, use of recreational drugs, or history of sickle cell disease. Upon further questioning, he mentions that he recently started a new medication for his depression and insomnia. His past medical history is unremarkable. On examination, the patient appears distressed. There is a fully turgid, painful penis without any signs of trauma. Urinalysis is within normal limits.  Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trazodone

 

Option C:

 

Priapism is a prolonged and painful erection that lasts for more than 4 hours and is unrelated to sexual stimulation. It is a urological emergency, as failure to treat can lead to fibrosis and permanent erectile dysfunction. Trazodone, an atypical antidepressant frequently prescribed off-label for insomnia, is well known for causing priapism as a side effect. The exact mechanism is unknown, but it is thought that trazodone's antagonism of alpha-1 adrenergic and histamine receptors could play a role. While priapism is a rare side effect of trazodone, when a patient on this medication presents with an unexplained prolonged erection, it should be high on the differential.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fluoxetine can cause sexual dysfunction but is not typically associated with priapism.

 

Option B: Lithium can cause several side effects, including tremor and thyroid dysfunction, but not priapism.

 

Option D: Lamotrigine does not commonly cause priapism as a side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trazodone and nefazodone are classified as SARI (serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor). The mechanism of action is weak inhibition of serotonin reuptake and strong antagonism at 5 HT2A and 5 HT2C receptors. Trazodone can cause priapism as a side effect.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 640.

questions.text: An 82-year-old retired army veteran is brought to the clinic by his concerned daughter. She recounts how, over the past 4 months, following the unexpected death of his only son, her father's demeanor has drastically changed. He often stares out the window, lost in thought, and breaks down in tears at the mention of his son's name. He has been expressing feelings of worthlessness and recently confided in her about considering "ending it all." She's also noticed a drop in his appetite, with him unintentionally losing a significant amount of weight. His medical history is significant for benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypertension, type 2 diabetes managed with insulin, and a prior heart attack 5 years ago. Given his complex medical history, which medication would be best suited to address his depressive symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sertraline

 

Option C:

 

The description of the 82-year-old retired army veteran indicates he is likely suffering from major depressive disorder, particularly following the bereavement of his son. In selecting an appropriate antidepressant for him, it is important to consider his age, medical comorbidities, and the side effect profile of the medication. Sertraline (SSRI) is often preferred in elderly patients due to its relatively favorable side effect profile, especially in the context of multiple comorbidities. SSRIs are generally safer in terms of cardiac side effects and have a lower risk of anticholinergic effects (which can exacerbate benign prostatic hyperplasia and cause urinary retention) and orthostatic hypotension. They are also safer in case of overdose compared to other classes of antidepressants.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Doxepin and B) Amitriptyline are tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs). They are generally avoided in older patients due to their anticholinergic side effects (which can worsen benign prostatic hyperplasia and cause urinary retention, constipation, and dry mouth), orthostatic hypotension, and potential cardiac side effects (especially relevant in a patient with a history of heart attack).

 

Option D: Tranylcypromine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI). MAOIs are typically used as a last resort due to their numerous dietary restrictions and potential for severe interactions with other medications, making them less suitable for elderly patients with multiple comorbidities and on multiple drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In elderly patients with depression, especially those with multiple comorbidities, SSRIs like sertraline are generally preferred due to their favorable side effect profile and safety in case of overdose. They are often the first line for treating depression in the elderly. Tricyclic antidepressants and MAOIs are usually avoided in the elderly due to their higher risk of side effects and interactions.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 675.

choices.text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of recurrent major depressive disorder is being managed with medication in your clinic. She is a nutrition enthusiast and reads about an experimental tryptophan-free amino acid mixture that she decides to try. A week later, she reports a noticeable worsening of her depressive symptoms. Given the role of tryptophan in neurotransmitter synthesis, which of the following treatments she might be on is most likely responsible for the observed exacerbation of her symptoms upon tryptophan depletion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)

 

Option A:

 

The observed exacerbation of depressive symptoms in the patient who tried a tryptophan-free amino acid mixture can be most directly related to her treatment with Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs). Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor to serotonin, a neurotransmitter implicated in mood regulation and the target of SSRIs. SSRIs work by blocking the reuptake of serotonin in the brain, thereby increasing its availability in the synaptic cleft. However, if the synthesis of serotonin is compromised due to a lack of its precursor, tryptophan, the efficacy of SSRIs could be reduced, potentially leading to a worsening of depressive symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Tricyclic antidepressants: While TCAs also affect serotonin levels, they do so by a different mechanism compared to SSRIs and also impact other neurotransmitters like norepinephrine.

 

Option C: Reboxetine: This is a norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and its mechanism of action is primarily on the norepinephrine system, not serotonin.

 

Option D: Cognitive behavioral therapy: This is a psychotherapeutic approach and is not directly affected by biological changes related to tryptophan levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) function by blocking the reuptake of serotonin in the synaptic cleft, increasing its availability in the synapse. When there's a depletion of tryptophan, and consequently serotonin, the therapeutic effect of SSRIs can be compromised, potentially exacerbating depressive symptoms.

 

Ref: Stahl’s Neuroscientific basis and practical applications, 5th edition, Page No 289.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with a two-week history of persistent sadness, loss of interest in activities, significant weight loss, and recurrent thoughts of death. She has no past medical history, and her physical examination is unremarkable. Given her presentation of acute severe depression, the clinician aims to initiate pharmacotherapy with a medication that has a favorable side-effect profile. Which of the following drugs is considered the drug of choice for acute severe depression with the least side effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitor (SNRI)

 

Option D:

 

The management of acute severe depression requires careful consideration of the efficacy and side-effect profile of antidepressant medications. D) Serotonin-noradrenaline reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) such as venlafaxine and duloxetine are effective for severe depression and generally have a more favorable side-effect profile compared to TCAs and MAO inhibitors. They are often well-tolerated and have become a common choice for the treatment of severe depression.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitors are effective for depression but are associated with significant side effects and dietary restrictions due to the risk of hypertensive crisis with the ingestion of tyramine-rich foods.

 

Option B: Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) are also effective but are associated with anticholinergic side effects, sedation, and cardiotoxicity, especially in overdose, making them less favorable, particularly in patients with suicidal ideation.

 

Option C: Serotonin modulators, such as trazodone, can be useful but are not typically considered first-line for severe depression. They can also have side effects such as sedation and, rarely, priapism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most of the studies have found that all the classes of antidepressants have same efficacy. However some studies have found that SNRIs to be more effective than SSRIs. This is attributed to the action of SNRIs on both norepinephrine as well as serotonin receptors. TCAs too act on multiple receptors but are associated with serious side effects.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 632-633.

questions.text: In the context of antidepressant use, the "placebo effect" is most strongly associated with which of the following psychiatric disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mild depression

 

Option A:

 

Mild depression has been consistently associated with a high placebo response rate in clinical trials of antidepressant medications. Patients with milder symptoms are more likely to experience significant improvement with placebo treatment, possibly due to the natural fluctuation of depressive symptoms or the psychosocial aspects of receiving care.

 

The placebo effect refers to the improvement of symptoms due to the patient's belief in the efficacy of a treatment, rather than the treatment's actual pharmacological effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: OCD typically has a lower placebo response rate. The chronic and often severe nature of OCD might contribute to this, as well as the specific and intense nature of the obsessions and compulsions associated with the disorder.

 

Option C: Specific phobias are usually treated with behavioral interventions like exposure therapy, not antidepressants. While placebo effects can occur in the treatment of phobias, they are not as strongly associated with placebo responses as mild depression.

 

Option D: Generalized anxiety disorder does have a placebo response, but not to the extent observed in mild depression. Antidepressants can be effective in treating GAD, but the placebo effect is something clinicians need to be aware of.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Placebo effect is particularly pronounced in the treatment of mild depression with antidepressants.

 

Ref: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 307.

questions.text: Ms. R, a 37-year-old woman, is admitted to the inpatient psychiatric unit following her third suicide attempt in the past two years. The nursing staff reports that she often remains in bed for the majority of the day, rarely interacts with others, and has been frequently observed crying. A review of her medical records indicates a significant weight loss of 18 kg over the past two years. Given the acute severity and risk associated with her condition, you are considering various treatment options to address her immediate needs. Which of the following treatment modalities would be least appropriate as an initial intervention for Ms. R's current presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brief psychodynamic therapy

 

Option A:

 

Brief psychodynamic therapy: While this approach explores unconscious processes and patterns, it doesn't offer the immediate symptom relief needed in acute cases like Ms. R's, making it the least appropriate initial intervention.

 

Ms. R's severe depressive symptoms and recent suicide attempt necessitate interventions that can rapidly reduce symptoms and risk of self-harm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT): Effective for depression, it offers coping tools. However, its success hinges on active patient participation, which might be challenging in acute distress.

 

Option C: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT): A potent intervention for severe depression, ECT can swiftly alleviate symptoms, especially in cases resistant to other treatments.

 

Option D: Pharmacotherapy: Antidepressants can be commenced immediately, addressing the depression's neurochemical aspects. They may take time for full effect but can begin symptom relief sooner.

 

Considering the need for rapid intervention in Ms. R's case, brief psychodynamic therapy is the least appropriate initial option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe depression with acute suicidality or significant functional impairment, rapid and effective treatments like ECT or pharmacotherapy are usually prioritized over therapies that may have a slower onset of therapeutic effects.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 393.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female is undergoing therapy for recurrent depressive episodes. During the sessions, her psychiatrist focuses on identifying, challenging, and altering her negative thought patterns and beliefs. The therapist works with her to develop healthier ways of thinking and behaving. Based on this approach, which type of psychotherapy is the patient most likely receiving?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cognitive behavioral therapy

 

Option B:

 

The description of the therapy focusing on identifying, challenging, and altering negative thought patterns and beliefs, and developing healthier ways of thinking and behaving, is characteristic of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). CBT is a widely used form of psychotherapy that combines cognitive and behavioral techniques to treat various mental health conditions, including depression. It is based on the premise that negative thought patterns contribute to psychological distress and maladaptive behaviors, and by altering these thoughts, one can improve emotional well-being and behavior.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Psychodynamic Psychotherapy: This form of therapy focuses on exploring unconscious processes as they are manifested in a person's present behavior. The goals are to increase self-awareness and understanding of the influence of the past on present behavior.

 

Option C: Behavioral Therapy: This approach focuses solely on changing maladaptive behaviors through techniques like conditioning, without the cognitive aspect of challenging and changing thought patterns.

 

Option D: Interpersonal Therapy: This therapy focuses on interpersonal relationships and social functioning, aiming to improve communication patterns and how people relate to others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) is a form of psychotherapy that focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors, with the aim of improving mental well-being. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 767-771.
